content: One of the great privileges of being the editor in chief of BioScience is that I get to preview the new issue. It is unimaginably rewarding to see the final product of the peer review process, reflecting the creativity of the authors, identification of leading scholars to review the manuscripts by the BioScience editorial board, thoughtful ad hoc reviews and assessments by the editorial board members, and careful responses by the authors, sometimes through multiple submissions. The scope of articles and knowledge presented in BioScience is breathtaking, beyond the comprehension of any one editor in chief; therefore, what the reader sees represents a truly gratifying peer review collaboration among the scientific community. Also, because of the number of manuscripts that come across my desk—more than 300 in 2023—it is a pleasant surprise to see the initial submissions organized into an issue. As you can imagine, supervising so many manuscripts results in my inability to remember the details of our successful submissions—a fuzzy recollection at best. However, writing an editorial that highlights the content provides the opportunity to think of what was and what became.
